intro: Heracleum nepalense var. bivittatum, commonly known as the Nepal cowparn, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. It is native to the Himalayan regions of Nepal and northern India, thriving in temperate climates with well-drained soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring hollow, grooved stems and finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in complex umbels, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. This variant is distinguished by its two distinct longitudinal stripes on the stem, giving it its specific epithet "bivittatum."
